name: 陳紅章
objective:
幫助學生認識一般科技文章以及科技論文語法、文體、句子結構等，並加強英文口頭表達之能力。
This course helps the learners recognize the syntax, style, and organization as far as the papers on technology and technical writings are concerned. Discussions include specific ways to technical presentation and technical writings.
schedule:
Weeks 1-2: Introduction to Presentation Skills for Postgraduates
Overview of the course objectives
Importance of presentation skills for postgraduate students
Self-assessment of current presentation skills

Weeks 3-4: Understanding Your Audience
Identifying and analyzing the audience
Adapting presentations for different audiences
Tailoring content to meet audience expectations

Weeks 5-6: Structuring Effective Presentations
Introduction to presentation structure
Crafting compelling introductions and conclusions
Organizing main points for clarity

Weeks 7-8: Visual Design and Support
Creating effective visual aids (slides, charts, graphs)
Principles of design and layout for presentations
Ensuring visual coherence and simplicity

Weeks 9-10: Verbal and Nonverbal Communication
Improving vocal delivery (pitch, pace, tone)
Body language and gestures
Managing nervousness and building confidence

Weeks 11-12: Data Visualization and Interpretation
Best practices for presenting data
Choosing the right visualization for different data types
Interpreting and conveying data effectively

Weeks 13-14: Practice Sessions and Peer Feedback
Short practice presentations by participants
Peer feedback and constructive criticism
Tips for giving and receiving feedback

Weeks 15-16: Advanced Presentation Techniques
Handling Q&A sessions effectively
Dealing with unexpected challenges during presentations
Strategies for engaging and maintaining audience interest

Weeks 17-18: Final Project and Review
Participants create a comprehensive presentation on their research or a relevant topic
Final presentations with peer evaluations
Review of key concepts and skills, with an emphasis on continuous improvement
materials: "Presentation Skills for Scientists A Practical Guide" by Edward Zanders and Lindsay MacLeod
